Comments_List:
As first-year Ph.D. students, it's good (and necessary) to be able to meet each member of our new department. It's also very nice to be able to have a dedicated time to discuss relevant academic topics with our new cohort. However, the structure of the course is perhaps less than ideal, and we are left with a somewhat arbitrary understanding of any topics.

I can think of [at least] two better structuring methods for this course.

1: We survey key topics in Ecology and Evolution, with each professor giving a lecture on a fundamental concept relevant to their research
2: We survey key "canon" papers in Ecology and Evolution, with each professor guiding a discussion on the paper.

The upside would be a much better, broader introduction to key ideas. Further, some of the faculty tend to enjoy mentioning the many classic papers we haven't read, so why not read them all together? The downside is that each professor would have to put in additional work.
